Award.AwardTitle: Engineering a DNA-based nanodevice to enable cytosolic transport of enzymes

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract

Proposal Number: 1402756
P.I.: Muro, Silvia
Institution: University of Maryland College Park
Title: Engineering a DNA-based nanodevice to enable cytosolic transport of enzymes

This project aims at designing tools to enable safe, specific, and efficient access into the interior of live cells, which is elusive to current technologies. This is achieved by leveraging on the material that cells naturally use to store their genetic information and re-engineering this material into tiny devices capable to interact and be transported into cells. The project encompasses characterization of these devices, evaluation of their interaction with live cells, and investigation of their effects. By providing access into live cells, this technology has a very broad potential: it can be used to study how cells function and also to manipulate their activity, which is important to enable research, to exploit cells as factories and machines, and to design new diagnostic and therapeutic tools. This has relevance to advance fundamental knowledge in a variety of disciplines, such as molecular and cellular biology, biomaterials, bioengineering, nanotechnology, etc., and to impact biotechnological production, biopharmaceutical development, and medical applications. The fundamental concepts, methods, and tools developed are also integrated into educational and training components, which involve high school, undergraduate, and graduate students, hence, contributing to training future scientists, engineers, educators, and other workforce. Products of this project are used for scientific divulgation to the specialized and broader community, as well as interaction with industry, to maximize its fundamental and translational impact at a local, national, and global level.

The objective of this project is to design and optimize a DNA-based nanodevice to enable safe, specific, and efficient access of biomolecules to the cell interior, which currently remains elusive. This is achieved by exploiting newly discovered properties of DNA, which arise from engineering this natural polymer into architectures different from those available in nature. Briefly, DNA is engineered to acquire a dendrimeric conformation functionalized to carry biomolecules and to target specific cell-surface markers, which renders precise interaction with selected cells, uptake via precise endocytic pathways, and cytosolic delivery with transport to intracellular sites of choice. The three aims explored include characterization of DNA systems with different biophysical properties, evaluation of their interaction with cells, and investigation of their effects in cells. This enables intracellular access of probes, modulatory agents, diagnostics, therapeutics, etc., which has applications in fundamental research, biotechnological production, biopharmaceutical development, and medical applications. By leveraging on diverse disciplines such as cellular biology, biotechnology, bioengineering, nanotechnology, and biopharmaceuticals, this project also contributes tools, methods, and knowledge pertaining to these areas. This is further integrated into educational and training components, which involve high school, undergraduate, and graduate students,
contributing to training the future workforce.

This award by the Biotechnology, Biochemical, and Biomass Engineering Program of the CBET Division is co-funded by the Instrument Development for Biological Research Program of the Division of Biological Infrastructure.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview: The primary objective of this project was to design a technology to access within cells in a way amenable to transport molecules within the cell interior in a specific, efficient, and safe manner, which remains an elusive task. We proposed to achieved this by engineering DNA into a platform device providing this function, shifting further an old paradigm that believed DNA unable to enter cells. For this purpose, the project focused on three main specific aims: (a) characterization of DNA devices with different biophysical properties, (b) evaluation of their interaction with cells, and (c) investigation of their effects in said cells.

Intellectual Merit: DNA is the most classical example of a molecule difficult to introduce into cells, requiring helping carriers to achieve such transport. However, in this project DNA was engineered to form a dendrimeric nanoparticle capable of interacting specifically with the cells of interest and to provide access of other molecules into said cells. Also, while classically DNA is introduced into cells to synthesize proteins intracellularly, DNA here was used to transport proteins into cells, avoiding the need for their intracellular synthesis. By providing specific, efficient, and safe access into cells, the technology produced through this project has a broad impact on many disciplines, since it renders intracellular access of probes, modulatory agents, diagnostics, and therapeutics into cells, which enables biotechnological production, biopharmaceutical development, and medical applications.

Broader Impact: This study encompassed a variety of disciplines, inlcuding cellular biology, recombinant DNA technology, biotechnology, nanotechnology, and biopharmaceuticals, all of which coalesced here into an emerging area: that of engineering DNA entities to display new functions and control interactions with biological systems. Therefore, this project has contributed tools, methods, and knowledge pertaining to all of these areas, also bringing awareness of the potential of interdisciplinary research and skills. This was possible by integrating the project and its products into educational and training components, including modules within formal courses and educational programs where high school, undergraduate, and graduate students were involved. Therefore, the benefit of the project extended to the future workforce, where a particular emphasis was successfully placed into engaging groups underrepresented in STEM disciplines. The products of this project were also used for outreach events in the community, scientific divulgation, and entreprenurial activities, which allowed us to maximize its fundamental and translational impact at a local, national, and international level.


Last Modified: 08/13/2017
Modified by: Silvia Muro
